item.title: By: protohedgehog
item.dc:creator: protohedgehog
item.description:
In reply to <a href="http://fossilsandshit.com/relocation-and-a-chance-to-try-some-open-science-ing/#comment-323">Graham Steel (@McDawg)</a>.
Cheers for the info McDawg! I do foresee a change in the style of writing. It might be necessary just to actually get interest in the idea, as opposed to being outwardly cynical/critical about pretty much everything ;)
item.content:encoded:
In reply to Graham Steel (@McDawg).

item.title: By: Graham Steel (@McDawg)
item.dc:creator: Graham Steel (@McDawg)
item.description:
Great post, Jon.
Loads of food for thought. I am hungry, about to cook dinner, so shall leave #chunk1 of my response today for starters.
After the out of the blue demise of the Science3.0 platform earlier this year (sniffs), I was lost in the blogosphere where to post my stuff. I posted a couple of posts on my personal blog that I hadn't posted on since 2010 in the interim. whilst my Science3.0 posts are mostly off the grid, they are on a laptop somewhere in London (power cord is missing, so I will chase up that line of inquiry again).
When I was approached by FigShare to blog about Open Science there, we reached a Gentleman's Agreement via email. (Upon reflection, it took a phone call a few weeks later to "iron out the creases", as it were as to format, language, length etc.).
After submitting posts 1 & 2 , it became clear that my personal writing style did not fit "that glove".
#AFRSEFUTTOCK.
Given the options available, I changed my style of writing that I had gotten used to since 2007 when I started blogging (thanks to a massive nudge from Bora Zivkovic)..
It took a few weeks to get used to it. Initially, I found this immeasurably unaccommodating from free-styling since 2007, but by post 4, I've never looked back.
It's all about communication, whether it be online or offline, so that is my starter (chilli sauce still defrosting).
Where I can, I refine my style of writing into the style that I have too.
*A separate outlet may have to be found for this, if (=when) needed"
Having more than one bloggy output does come in handy.
Mr McDawg
item.content:encoded:
Great post, Jon.

Loads of food for thought. I am hungry, about to cook dinner, so shall leave #chunk1 of my response today for starters.

After the out of the blue demise of the Science3.0 platform earlier this year (sniffs), I was lost in the blogosphere where to post my stuff. I posted a couple of posts on my personal blog that I hadn’t posted on since 2010 in the interim. whilst my Science3.0 posts are mostly off the grid, they are on a laptop somewhere in London (power cord is missing, so I will chase up that line of inquiry again).

When I was approached by FigShare to blog about Open Science there, we reached a Gentleman’s Agreement via email. (Upon reflection, it took a phone call a few weeks later to “iron out the creases”, as it were as to format, language, length etc.).

After submitting posts 1 & 2 , it became clear that my personal writing style did not fit “that glove”.

#AFRSEFUTTOCK.

Given the options available, I changed my style of writing that I had gotten used to since 2007 when I started blogging (thanks to a massive nudge from Bora Zivkovic)..

It took a few weeks to get used to it. Initially, I found this immeasurably unaccommodating from free-styling since 2007, but by post 4, I’ve never looked back.

It’s all about communication, whether it be online or offline, so that is my starter (chilli sauce still defrosting).

Where I can, I refine my style of writing into the style that I have too.

*A separate outlet may have to be found for this, if (=when) needed”

Having more than one bloggy output does come in handy.

Mr McDawg
